body.p: In this provocative interview with Gale and Vance, Nigel Holden, an internationally recognized scholar on knowledge management across cultures, talks about the relationship between tacit and explicit knowledge and the importance of managing these differences in business. While past research has considered the influence of culture in areas such as the applications of ethics in international business and expatriate international adjustment (Beyer & Nino, 1999; Bird, Osland, Mendenhall, & Schneider, 1999), few researchers besides Holden have examined the active influence of national culture within deep tacit and more explicit levels of knowledge across global society. Holden believes the West undervalues tacit knowledge, a cross-cultural knowledge sharing that arises from experience and intuition. He challenges some of the traditional cornerstones of cross-cultural understanding, specifically Hofstede’s, Trompenaars’s, and the GLOBE project’s models that focus on values, because in his view they create abstractions and stereotypes instead of “common cognitive and emotional ground” that he says is inherently subjective. Holden believes managers must be aware of the gaps and distortions in knowledge transfer that result from differences in language because these differences can undermine business strategies and unintentionally hijack an otherwise successful business transaction. Companies can successfully manage knowledge if they develop common cognitive ground across cultures in part by understanding the differences between Western or cerebral-based knowledge and Eastern or heart-based, tacit knowledge. As some may question this dichotomy, they create space for future work on this topic.
